document.docAuthor: Oliveira, Cléo D. C., Sartori, André F. & Absalão, Ricardo S.
document.masterDocTitle: Error cascade in taxonomy: The case of Cardiomya perrostrata (Mollusca: Bivalvia: Cuspidariidae) in Brazilian waters

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Error cascade in taxonomy: The case of Cardiomya perrostrata (Mollusca: Bivalvia: Cuspidariidae) in Brazilian waters

Redescription. Shell small (max. height: 13 mm ; max. length: 25 mm , USNM 95 393), inequivalve, with left valve slightly overlapping right valve along ventral margin. Shell flank globose, umbones prominent and blunt. Rostrum elongated, longer and more curved in larger specimens. Posterior margin slightly curved upwards, posteroventral sinuation gently marked, crenulated, ventral and anterior margins rounded, anterodorsal margin forming a well-marked shoulder. Larval shell type 2D, ca. 215–235 µ m in length. Nepioconch smooth, ca. 1 mm in length. Dissoconch with 20–25 radial ribs, the 4–5 strongest ribs ornament the posterior end of the shell flank, just anterior to the rostrum; rostrum with 7–10 radial riblets and arenophilic lines. Periostracum minutely pitted. Hinge plate narrow, left valve edentulous, right valve with strong posterior lateral tooth. Lithodesma present.

Remarks. Figure 2 A illustrates the largest shell studied herein, measuring 25 mm in length. This seems to be the only known individual of
C. perrostrata
with a shell length exceeding 10 mm ; most valves of the species range from 6–10 mm in length.

Cardiomya perrostrata
displays a gradual increase in the relative length of the rostrum during its ontogeny and in larger specimens the rostrum is more prominently curved upwards ( Fig. 1 ). Some individual variation is also observed in the strength of radial ribs, especially those at the posterior half of the shell. Variation in these features, which are regarded as diagnostic for
Cardiomya
species, is probably the main culprit for the high incidence of misidentifications of
C. perrostrata
in the literature. It is most often confused with
C. ornatissima
(Orbigny, 1853 in 1842–1853 ),
C. cleryana
(
Orbigny, 1842
in 1834–1847 ) and
C. striata ( Jeffreys, 1876 )
.

Cardiomya ornatissima
( Fig. 3 A) differs from
C. perrostrata
in displaying fewer (4–6) and more widely spaced radial ribs, particularly towards the posterior margin. Additionally, in
C. ornatissima
the rostrum is curved downwards and the posteroventral sinuation is not marked.

Cardiomya cleryana
( Fig. 3 B) can be distinguished from
C. perrostrata
by its shorter rostrum, posteroventral sinuation gently curved and shell trigonal to elliptical.

Cardiomya striata
( Fig. 3 C) differs from
Cardiomya perrostrata
in having an elliptical shell, larger umbones, shorter rostrum, and radial ribs that are equidistant and more or less equal in prominence.

Geographic distribution. Figure 4 plots all records of
C. perrostrata
known to us. The majority of records originate from checklists and ecological studies that are insufficiently illustrated and usually unvouchered (Appendix 1). Records for which we could corroborate the correct identification of
C. perrostrata
by the examination of vouchers or figures were plotted as triangles on the map.

The distribution of
C. perrostrata
is Western Atlantic , with records ranging from 42°N (Gulf of Maine ) to 30°S ( Tramandaí , Brazil ), in depths of
18 m
(
Bishof 1980
) to
1646–1829 m
(
USNM 811156
). Mean depth of records is 381.9 m (median = 223.8 m), but we could only confirm the taxonomic identification of four records shallower than
200 m
.
If only verified records are considered, the species mean depth is 582.6 m (median =
620 m
) ( Fig. 4A ).

Confirmed occurrences are as follows (See the discussion section for notes on records marked with “?”): United States , Massachusetts , South of Martha’s Vineyard , around Block and Alvim canyons ( Allen & Morgan 1981 ;
Verrill
1881
– 1882 ; Verrill & Bush 1898 ); off Miame ,
